Blog.post: Pondering the Mountaintop Hello everybody! I was talking to my mom one morning, and she was telling me about this cool thing she read in her devo book, and I thought I'd post it. She was saying how in the Old Testament, when Moses went up to Mount Sinai and was talking to God, he asked God to show him His face. Then God said He couldn't, cuz His full presence would kill Moses, but He showed Moses part of His presence. When Moses came down from the mtn., he was covered in the glory of God and just glowing. All the people in the village thingy, or whatever they lived in, asked if they could get that too, so Moses led a bunch of them to the top of the mtn. At the top, God was showing Himself in a huge thrundercloud with lightning and thunder and stuff. Moses told the people to walk inside of the cloud, cuz that's where they would find God, but they were afraid, and wouldn't do it. So he went inside the cloud and was calling them from inside, telling them that they should just take the step from the edge into the cloud. But they were too afraid, and therefore, missed out completely from seeing a beautiful experience with God. A lot of times, we do that in worship, prayer, faith, or whatever God wants us to do, for that matter. We get the the edge of the cloud and just get too freaked out to just take that one step into His glory. And we miss out. So I was thinking about that, and thought about how those people must've felt when the came down from the mountaintop. Probably the way we do when we come back from Spring Fling, a prayer retreat, etc. Charged up, but still thinking, in the backs of their minds, 'I didn't do enough. I should've taken the step into God.' Of course, most of us never talk about it, and we just brush that feeling away. But it's true. I mean, to be honest, there are so many times that I know God's leading me somewhere, but I get too scared to completely let go of it, and just ask if maybe He could hold off for another day. And I miss my chance. So I think that this is something everyone can relate to, and can use to really find out what's truly keeping them from God's presence. Pride, selfishness, fear, inhibitions? We all have things that keep us from going 100% for God 100% of the time, and I think that if all of us in Fusion, and especially on the worship team, let go to God, maybe we'd be in a different place. Not that where we are is bad or anything, but I know sometimes it's really hard to get into worship onstage. I dunno, maybe I'm alone here, but I thought I'd post this, becuz I can't help but wonder what if. ~Erika <>

Worship for Nov. 9 I just wanted to say how great I thought last nite at Fusion was! I mean, it seemed so much like we were a team, and more so than it really ever has been. I had just been praying that day that God would really show up, and He totally did. The congregation got into it pretty well, and more than that, the worship team was so in tune! I mean, it was weird cuz that was exactly what I had been asking God for. I noticed a couple mistakes here and there, and Jaime and I even forgot our parts for Breathe, but it didn't matter at all. It flowed so well, and even when something weird happened, we knew it happened, but it didn't matter at all...no one got thrown off or anything? Isn't that so amazing? God is so incredible, and I'm so thankful that we're finally starting to really worship as a GROUP, instead of as individuals sharing a stage. I understand from some perspectives that there was no unity whatsoever in the times before I was there, but even when I got there, it seemed really tense a lot. People would get frustrated with each other really easily, and overall, we were kinda messed up. But now, we are such a team, and I think that God is really trying to do something here. I had been talking to God about this for a while, and I kept feeling as though God has been trying to do something really incredible, but there were things on the team that were totally hindering Him. And Pastor Joe even talked about that today...how we can completely limit God's blessings. I think there were some really bad attitudes on some peoples' minds, and I think that although it's not completely gone, it's getting better, and we've relaxed a lot more. We've really realized (ALL of us) that it's not about us. I mean, we say that all the time, but I mean, come on...I know a lot of people didn't take it seriously all the time, and I know I was guilty of it! So I'm glad that now we've just finally gotten to a point where we're really on the road to where God is leading us. Tension has really dissipated, and patience has begun to take its place. I'm so in awe of God, you guys! He is so good!! This makes me wonder how people can just not get into worship...just things like this that make us really happy we're in His will, ya know? ~Erika <>

Worship for Nov. 23 (It Just Gets Better!!) Wow, worship last Saturday nite was incredible! Everything flowed so well, especially at the end. The sermons by Michael and Dono were really good, and I think they woke people up a little. During the first worship, I noticed a lot of people sitting around and some talking, but later that nite, so many people were getting into God! I mean, wow!! And everything flowed so well that I think we're really growing as a team, guys. The more we become a team, the more God can use us to work through, and we're getting there faster than I thought we were. And although a lot of people left later towards the end, God hadn't left at all. Some of us just kept going with it, and it only got better. We're getting there guys, and it'll only keep getting better. ~Erika <>

The Ark on Jan. 12 The trip to the Ark was really good, in my opinion. It was strange that I was really not nervous at all...I hate being in the spotlight--Jaime is only slightly worse than me. Jaime, Nat, and Haley went up to the girls' camp to encourage people to go, and Michael and I stayed back to practice worship. Ok, fine, I will admit that I was pretty nervous before people came in, but that's weird too, that I wasn't nervous when a ton of people were in there. Anyway...I was kinda thrown off, cuz like an idiot, I procrastinated listening to the cd Michael gave me that had One Thing on it. I figured, well, I've heard the song before, so I'm sure picking out a harmony'll be a piece of cake. No. I sat there on Saturday nite for a half an hour listening to that one song, and I couldn't find a harmony, except for little snatches of it here and there...frustration!! So in the end I wound up singing melody with him...it's weird to sing melody anymore cuz I'm so used to singing harmony to virtually every song! It was kinda strange before Nat got there to sing during the actual service, cuz before she got there, I was the only girl singing, and I felt really exposed...I'm so not used to being in the spotlight or really even being heard in worship at all, lol. But in the end it went really well, and when Nat got there, it added a little more fullness to the songs. Overall, I think everything sounded really good. Adam got up and did his sermon thing, and that went really well. I think he needs to be some kind of professional speaker or something, cuz he's so well-spoken, even when he's just talking in a normal conversation. He didn't sound nervous at all, which is saying something, cuz I know that when I get up in front of people to talk, my voice gets kinda shaky and stuff...ugh. Anyway, so yeah, his sermon went really well and then Pastor Rick got up and did a kinda altar-call thingy, only it was more like he was just talking about the benefits of God. It was really good. I think I want to go up more on Sundays, cuz it was really fun, even if I didn't really connect with anyone. I think that if I went up more I would wind up clicking with someone, and that would be fun, cuz most of them are really nice, they're just hard to talk to at first. So anyway, just wanted to talk about the Ark and everything since my blog is pretty much devoted to ministry. Oh, and lesson learned--when someone gives you something to listen to, listen to it sooner than 10 hours before you're supposed to sing it!! ;o) ~Erika <>

Worship for January 11 Worship Saturday nite was so awesome! I mean, lately it's seemed that the congregation has been kinda...blah (this excludes the 28th, cuz I heard that was really good). I don't know everyone's hearts, so I don't know if they're really getting into it or if they're just bored. But it's been kinda frustrating. So it was really nice to be standing on the risers, worshiping, and then open my eyes to see so many people jumping around. I was so blessed! I could really feel God there, and it was so incredible to feel freedom in Him, the way we haven't seen at Fusion for a long time. Although yes, there are always the one-sey, two-sey people jumping (Meg, Bobby, Michael, Zack), we used to have so many more people just dancing. However, we have been missing Dono, so that explains a lot. ;o) This may sound kinda hypocritical, cuz I'm not someone who really is a dancer in worship...I tend to want to be in the back lately so that I feel more free to do whatever without feeling peoples' eyes on me (whether they are or I'm just paranoid I don't know), but typically I don't jump around unless I'm really, really, really into it. So it probably sounds kinda hypocritical to say it's frustrating to not see other people jumping around. To quote the girl from YWAM who painted bookmarks: "Worship is a heart posture, not a physical posture...though often the former expresses itself in the latter." I guess what I'm trying to say is that I haven't really felt God truly move in Fusion for a good month or more, and the people who are usually all over the place, or at least clapping, half-yelling/singing, or even raising their hands were not. So what I'm really saying is that I really saw and felt God move Saturday night, and I felt blessed to be a part of it. Our team continues to grow closer together, and it's so awesome to see that happening. God is going to do something with us, guys, but He can't do it till we're all moved into the right position. Therefore, it is so crucial that we work together, and so beautiful to see that actually occuring. What James said before practice has really stuck with me, about how we used to have to pray every time for no stress, attitudes, or tempers, and how we don't even say that anymore. I don't know how to express how grateful I am to be a part of a team that is becoming so unified so quickly, and under some of the most unlikely circumstances and pressures. ~Erika <> PS--I found this really cool quote in my Nichole Nordeman cd...it really doesn't have anything to do with what I just wrote, but I thought I'd put it in cuz I felt like it: "She who reconciles the ill-matched threads of her life, and weaves them gratefully into a single cloth - it's she who drives the loudmouths from the hall and clears it for a different celebration where the one guest is You." --Rainer Maria Rilke.

125 x 25 Wow, Saturday nite was so amazing! I mean, aside from the obviously cool fact of having 160 people, worship was so good!! It was so much fun to see everyone getting into it, and it's just such a blessing to know that God's working thru you to lead people into His presence. I came in that day after having a really crappy day...my mom and I had been arguing in the car, and then when I was able to actually leave the car, the first thing I encounter was a friend say "You're in big trouble!" She was only joking, but I was so not in the mood, cuz I knew I was late, so I was thinking maybe I am in trouble? So I come in and someone runs up and tells me that we're learning a new song...I didn't know it was Dance in the River, which is really easy cuz there're no harmonies yet...but I was thinking, 'Oh crap, I have to figure out a harmony, and Kevin Brewton's not here!' So the stress was really setting in, on top of the bad mood I was already in. Then I had about 5 people come up and ask me if I was ok, which is nice to hear that they care, but at the time I just wanted to go into the bathroom or something and just be alone and quiet for about 10 minutes. I was just getting really emotional about really dumb stuff, and I was so tense over everything, and I kept telling myself, 'Erika, get a hold of yourself! You're at worship practice now, everything's fine, you're gonna live!' So I started to calm down and I was just trying to pray in my head and become rational again. So the stress really only lasted about 10 minutes, but still, I just wanted to hurry up and get started on everything and forget about me. We're in a circle praying, and someone who shall remain nameless (JAMES!), lol, asked me if I was ok, which was really nice, but then like 5 people swiveled around and looked at me and I was like, 'Ok, I'm officially ready to crawl under a rock!!' (But thanx James, cuz it was really cool of you, I needed it.) So yeah, after that, everything really was ok, and the new song was way easy, since the background vocalists do almost nothing. So my point was, it was way awesome to see all these people getting into worship, and for myself, to just let go of all the crap going on in the real world and focus on God. It was so what I needed, and to see everyone getting into God and really going for it was such a tremendous blessing. I feel kinda bad cuz I wasn't able to invite anyone to the service though, cuz I wrote my list before Pastor Rick said we needed to invite these people to 125x25. One person doesn't even live here, and then 2 people I don't have their numbers, and then the last person had a basketball game. So I'm really not sure why I just went into this huge thing about my irrational problems, but I think I was just saying that it doesn't matter where you are or how you feel, but if you let go to God, He'll totally take you to a new level with Him, where you can forget about everything, and all's right with the world (wish I could build a summer home there!!). It was such a blessing to me, personally, to see so many people being ushered into God's presence just like I was...forgetting about everything and just seeking the one answer to every problem. ~Erika <>

Saturday Was So Fun!!! (Worship Feb. 8) Oh yeah!! I think practice was so much fun on Saturday, and I don't really know why...nothing really exciting. I just was in a really good mood I guess. And then I talked to James, who talked to me about having Jaime and me play keys. I am so looking forward to that cuz I really have felt like God is calling me to start doing that. I've been practicing keys at home, cuz I play piano anyway, and it's become so dang easy. I thought, 'Well, if Stacy's not here sometime, I can just play for her,' and then I thought about how it might be a bit weird not being able to ever you know, not hafta be up there playing keys, if we're playing every week now. But then James told me that Jaime's gonna start playing too, so now we'll be able to alternate, and that's totally awesome! God is so good, and He just opens all the right doors at all the right times! So anyway, sorry, back to worship practice. But yeah, so that went really well, and then when we really got going into the service, wow! I mean, it was pretty dead the first few songs, and that wasn't fun, but then Pastor Rick got up and talked, and the whole baptism thing happened. (So awesome!) Then after that, worship really, really got good. I think people were really awake by then (about time!!), but everyone was jumping around, and there was just such a spirit of freedom in that whole place! Dono's song is really good. Nicole helped us find a harmony to the chorus, and that was really good, cuz it needed some depth. I really hope we start doing more of our own stuff, you know? I mean, I love the stuff we do normally, but I think it'd be so fun to be doing stuff that's original. And then we learned Show Me Your Glory, which was really easy once Kevin Brewton and Nicole helped Jaime and me with the high harmony. I just had such a good time that nite. And then at the end, all of us singers, with the exception of Nicole, jumped off the stage and were jumping around, and that was so fun!! (Although, and I don't understand why, cuz I work out almost every day, my calves are still sore as I write this!) I think, personally, that Bobby should start leading some songs, cuz I think he has a great voice. And if he can jump while he's playing guitar, he can sing while he's doing it too, lol! Anyway, so yeah, it was just really awesome, and it's just been getting better for me personally, cuz I've been getting so much more comfortable being normal (in worship, strictly speaking, lol) onstage. Speaking of which, I was kinda surprised that I was asked to sing I Could Sing with Jaime, but it was really fun in worship, so I hope we get to do it sometime again. However, I've been told I need to back off mike cuz I'm overpowering Jaime...oops (sorry Jaime!) It's really weird singing up front though, cuz I've never done it before with the band playing, and it's so loud ! Yeah, and I say that like I'm not used to being loud in my everyday life...but I wasn't nervous at all up there, which was majorly good, since Jaime had enough stagefright to supply everyone on that team. (jk Jaime!) So yeah, I don't know if any of this really makes any sense, cuz it's all kinda about different stuff, but I am just so glad that each week results in our team becoming more like a family, and so much more tightly knit. ~Erika <>

A Few Firsts (Worship Feb. 22) Saturday nite was really fun. For one thing, and probably the most dramatic, was that Jaime played keys with the group for the first time!! YAY!! Yeah, all week we were talking about it, and she was kinda nervous, but she did so well. The only thing to comment negatively on was the fact that the sound guys wouldn't turn her up enough, so we couldn't hear her much in the house. However, I could hear her onstage pretty well if I listened for her, and what I heard was really, really good. The keyboard is pretty old, and the number 7 sticks, but that's ok. She did really well playing, and especially in Hungry. I know she's been practicing that song all week every spare minute she can find! So yeah, anyway, another really cool thing was that as a band/team, we learned two new songs in one practice session! Isn't God so cool?? We learned History Maker, which to be honest, I really didn't like before, but now it's actually pretty cool. And then we learned Hungry (Falling on My Knees), and that was ok. I mean, musically, it was great, and Scott and Nicole sounded fine. But it was really my first time singing onstage, up front with the leaders for the service, and I was really disappointed in myself cuz I couldn't find a harmony worth crap!! Frustration!! So Nicole and I wound up having me sing an echo in the melody, and that was ok, but it didn't have the same quality vocally that I was looking for. I dunno...it just didn't have the right ring. I couldn't sing the high harmony, cuz it's pretty much a soprano range, and the middle harmony echo is too low. Ergh!! So yeah, I was really hoping I'd have found a much better thing to sing, cuz it wasn't quite what I was looking for, but overall, I think it sounded good, and as long as it can lead people into worship, that's all that really matters. History Maker sounded really good, in my opinion. The guitar in it was really fun, and then in Hungry, the drums and keys were really cool too. Anyway, so overall, I think practice went so well, and then the service was really awesome. It was Ignition, and Alpha and Vicky did the sermon. They did such a great job! I was especially impressed with Vicky, cuz she's normally so introverted around large groups of people that I was actually shocked when I asked her if she was interested in doing the sermon and she said yes! She had looked up a lot of the Hebrew/Greek translations, and she found a lot of links of different meanings in the Bible that I have no idea how she could have found, even on PC Study Bible. Although PCSB can confuse me sometimes. But yeah, I was really happy about how Saturday sounded and went overall. However, since Jaime played this past Saturday, that means I'm next for this coming weekend. And even though it's Sunday, and not even the week yet, I'm totally psyching myself out already! How lame is that?? But I know I can do this, but I'm just freaked out, partly subconciously, cuz I'm thinking about how maybe they're not gonna want me to play after how well Jaime did. Maybe that's really dumb, but I tend to be a bit of a pessimist when it comes to me playing piano. Like I said, I know I can do this, and I know God's called me to do this, so really, I have nothing at all to worry about, cuz as long as God's on my side, He's totally got me. I'm just paranoid freak sometimes. But anyway, all that aside, I am so proud of our team. It's so exciting to watch God really play a part in such a big way. That said, I'd like to end with a quote from my Nichole Nordeman cd, cuz I think it really describes us: "We stutter and we stammer till You say us--A symphony of chaos till You play us..." ~Erika <>

Worship March 1 Saturday nite was pretty good. I played for the first time on the worship team, and it was actually a lot better than I thought it would be. I had these pre-conceived ideas about all these horrible things happening, and none of them did, so I guess that's good! It was a little embarrassing having to have Michael go over the verse with me in Enough about 20 times, and it didn't help that the main leaders (James and Bobby) kept listening in. (No offense to them though, cuz I know it wasn't to make me nervous or anything.) I finally caught on, and it was really good to have Jaime there with me. I know she was singing and everything, but she could tell me which voices to put on what song, and could tell me if I was playing "too choppy"! (lol, James!) Then during the actual service I had a lot of fun. I mean, it was kinda hard at first cuz the first song was Dance in the River, and all through the first part all I do is hold the D chord down...for the whole first part. So I was trying to look like I'm giving my all for God, but I don't really think I could...and then it was really funny though cuz when everyone started dancing around, even onstage, everything was shaking...I had no idea that happened when I sang on the side! I'm just sitting there playing my little D and G chords, and the whole floor starts shaking, and the keyboard starts shaking...I almost laughed cuz it scared me really bad at first cuz I honestly thought the keyboard was gonna fall over or something! Whatever. So I made my way throught the rest of the songs, and it was actually a lot more worshipful than I thought it would be. I mean, at home when I'm playing by myself, I get into worship really well, but then again it doesn't matter if I mess up or not. So I didn't really count on actually getting into worship this nite, but I did. Overall, I think the night went really well...I had a really good time playing, and it wasn't as stressful as I thought it'd be. I definitely thought Bobby was gonna get all frustrated with me or something, but if he did he didn't show it, and for that I am grateful!! Oh, and he sounded great singing! Go Bobby!! Oh, and I'm glad that for that nite James didn't have me playing the verse in Enough, cuz it gave me some time just to sit there and raise my hands...that gesture used to be so casual, but now that I play, I'm grateful for the times when I actually can just raise my hands and start worshiping...weird, huh? ~Erika <>

Ark Ministry for March 16 Ok, going to the Ark was so awesome! I mean, first, worship was really fun. It's so weird cuz I get all nervous during practice, and then when everyone gets in there, I'm totally fine and nothing about it bothers me at all. Luckily none of the songs were new to me, so it went better than last time. I really like singing there, and I don't know why...anyway. Yeah, so the last time the Ark girls came to Fusion, someone did an altar call for if anyone needed anything, and I went down and started praying with this girl named Carrie Ann. It was really kinda depressing, cuz she was saying that she had a court thing she was going to the Tuesday after that nite, and she wanted prayer cuz she was kinda scared and she said she really wanted strength for going, becuz with all the charges against her, she said it was pretty likely she was going to go to jail. Well, so we prayed, and I asked her if she had a Bible, and she said no. So I went to Pastor Rick's office, and I got a Bible and some other stuff for her, and then I gave it to her, sat down, and never saw her again, assuming she went to jail. Well today at the Ark, I was sitting next to this girl named Andrea, and I asked if she knew Carrie Ann (I kinda wanted to find out what happened with her). "Yeah," she said, "she's fine, except she sprained her ankle, and she really wanted to come today, but she wasn't able cuz of her ankle." I was so surprised that she was still there! I told Andrea about what Carrie Ann had told me about the whole court/jail thing, and she said, "Well, she did go, but since her attitude was so good, they dropped every single charge." Isn't that so awesome??! I was so happy! So I really wanted to see her, but since she wasn't there, obviously I couldn't. That's why I'm kinda hoping I get to go to the Ark sometime again kinda soon, cuz I really want to talk to her. Anyway, so that was pretty much all I wanted to say, cuz I thought that God showed up for her so much that I had to tell about it! ~Erika <>

It Never Fails (Worship March 22) I had such a good time last nite. I played keys for the second time, and it never fails--I get so strung up and stressed before I play. I mean, during practice, I learned two new songs, and I was about to freak out cuz I Could Sing was really confusing me. I'm not really sure why, but Bobby really intimidates me (probably cuz he's such a good musician), so I was really glad he wasn't getting all frustrated with me (well, maybe he did, but I couldn't really tell). That one song was so frustrating to me cuz I had to ask him about five times how the chords went, or when this chorus is played when...poor guy. But I did finally get the hang of it, and all was well. The thing that I think is so weird is the contrast between being on the musician side verses being on the backup vocalist side. On the musician side (which I'm still pretty new to, so maybe that's why it's so foreign to me), it's so much more intense...you really have to focus so much more on it. It's actually nice, cuz if you've had a bad day, you totally forget it, becuz you have no free mind space to concentrate on anything but what you're playing, and if it's good or not (well, that's what happens to me anyway...unlike so many others on that team, it's not exactly effortless yet). On the other hand, you have the backup vocalist side, and it's so much more laid back. I mean, you can still pay attention and know what's going on, but singing is so much easier than playing...maybe becuz your throat is so much closer to your brain than your hands...? I'm not really sure which one I like better...I really like each one a lot, which is why I'm so glad I get to participate in both. Well, I came to youth in a really good mood, and I pretty much left in one too. Wow, bonus! And it never ceases to amaze me that when I really get into worship, everything else just flows. Like when I'm singing, it doesn't matter if I lose the harmony I was supposed to sing--it flows, and it blends. And it doesn't matter if I'm playing keys and I totally forget where I'm at and have to skip the whole rest of the line before I can catch back up--it still flows, and it still blends. I could never be a soloist...working with such great musicians really makes you understand a lot, especially how much you need them when they totally cover you when you screw up! But anyway, I thought the nite went really well, and I'm getting a lot more comfortable playing with the team. I guess I always thought I'd be really paranoid, becuz I have such an anxiety when it comes to playing in front of people, but when it's with this band, it doesn't matter at all...weird, huh? Gotta be God. Well, I guess that's about it...oh, and once again, I think Bobby did great singing. I think he underestimates himself vocally, which is really too bad, cuz his voice is so good...really strong and smooth. He just needs to hear it more; he'll get more comfortable with it. So I guess I said all this stuff, and totally forgot something that is a really big deal: God is always there--He always shows up, and it doesn't matter if you're singing, or playing, or both. He's there, and He always will reach you where you're at. For some reason that has become quite the profound reality to me lately. He's always by your side--but you set the pace. Are you gonna play to Him or play for Him? ~Erika <>

Why Worry? (Worship March 29) Last nite was so interesting. I have been feeling really weighed down by some insecurities lately, and I had had a talk on Thursday nite with two people who really made me understand how to get over it. It was really not something I wanted to get into with either of them cuz the reasons behind it are so stupid, but I am so glad I did...God spoke through them and really woke me up. Well Friday I wound up spending some time just talking to God, and I totally felt it leave. Any insecurity, doubt, or worry was just gone! It was so cool. And so then I came to youth on Saturday, and practice went so well. I got the hang of the harmonies and stuff really fast on I Could Sing, and things just flowed really well. And for some reason, I really like being in the front. Like I don't know if I want to lead really bad or anything, I just like being there. I can hear myself so much better, and I loved standing next to Nicole...her energy in worship is so contagious! I was really impressed by Michael leading, cuz although he's led before a lot, he's never led an entire worship session (or two, really, if you count the one after). I think he did so well...it was so awesome. So anyway, worship for me was so liberating. I was able to feel lighter almost, becuz all the other stuff I had had previously was just gone. I could really mean the words I was singing. I mean, it's not like worship is always some facade or something, but sometimes I just feel like I'm going through the motions, and my heart isn't really feeling what my mouth is singing, or what my hands are playing, ya know? But tonight I really let go of all the things that were holding me back, and although maybe I didn't start jumping off of chairs or anything, I just felt God so much more...it wasn't just singing, it was expressing gratitude and laying aside my humanity--something I haven't really done in a while. So anyway, it was just really great to feel so free and so unfettered by everything I'd been subconciously carrying. I was so glad to finally be able to feel God's presence as strongly as I did last nite, and I fully intend to feel it again. ~Erika <>

God is Incredible! I've been so stressed lately. I guess it's just been a steady accumulation of things that have amounted to a great deal of stress on me mentally and emotionally. I've been so worried about money for Costa Rica, and I really have no reason to be. Last time we went, my parents were planning on going, but when they decided against it, I got all the money they had raised. Basically, all the money I needed was handed to me on a silver platter. I know I did a bunch of the fundraisers, but I didn't need to--they only supplied me with about $30. However, this time I've had to really stand in faith for this. Even though it sounds really dumb, I'd say this is the hardest faith fight I've ever had the displeasure of partaking in. I know it was good for me, cuz it really taught me to rely on God more than anything, but it was so exhausting to me. I asked him that if I wasn't supposed to go to Costa Rica, to not even get me the first $60 deposit. Well, he did, and he got me everything else. The thing that always got me was that I would be totally calm, cool, and collected until about a week before the money's due date every time we had one, and the I would stress out so bad! For the last three deposits or so, I've had to learn patience, patience, and--oh! more patience! Each of those times, the money would come in mere days before the due date. However, the fact that God provided for each of them makes it totally illogical that I would stress about the next one, but it never failed--each time I would get so tense. I got bad grades on a couple of quizzes for school, I've been getting in trouble a little at home for my tone of voice (when I get stressed, I snap at people totally unintentionally...ugh), and I haven't been able to sleep as well. God is so good to me, and I don't know why I have trouble, sometimes, in giving him my full trust...it happens with big stuff like this, and I don't know why I let it get to me, when after all he's done for me, like he can't get me not even $2000 for something that's his will?? Back from Cancun Alright, I just got back from Cancun today. What a week...it was really nice to just lay out by the pool, put on my Discman, and think about nothing but whether or not this particular part of the day is best suited for tanning. It was good to just relax, and since I've just recently had to get all my exams for school done and raise all my money for Costa Rica, it was good to be able to get away from everything and do practically nothing for a week. However, part of me wishes that I would be able to go on vacations like that when I'm really really stressed and having problems with people in youth or something--you know, when you actually would rather be anywhere but here. But anyway, it was pretty fun--we had an all-inclusive thing, so we got room service whenever we wanted, and I learned how to make strawberry daiquiris (and how to actually spell that word. And of course I meant how to make them minus alcohol...cough.), and I got a massage for a half hr...yeah, that was one of the biggest highlights, except for the first like, 10 minutes I was really uncomfortable with having someone's hands on my butt--at least it was a woman, though. And then I got a manicure and pedicure, so yes, all in all, it was a good thing. I did miss youth and the people in it a lot, though. There were so many times I would hear or see something that would remind me of someone and it kinda made me sad cuz I realized how much I missed everyone. I hear the Fusion service went really well, and I'm glad to hear it--for some reason I kinda feel like my weekend has been incomplete if I haven't been to Fusion or church or...you know, something having to do with Impact. Oh, one of the biggest "duh" moments: realizing, walking down the Cancun terminal on the way to the baggage claim that I forgot to pack shorts. Oh yes! So we bought a couple of pairs and it was fine, but Lord...of all times to forget shorts, it's got to be in a place where the heat is so prominent. I learned how to barter while I was down there, and I also learned that...well, I guess I didn't really learn this part, I guess I just deepened my confusion: why do Mexican guys see a girl and act like they've never seen anything female before in their lives?? And why would they flirt with a white chick when they've got those beautiful, naturally tan women down there?? Yeah, didn't get it before Cancun, and don't get it now. And the legal drinking age is 18 down there--I also learned how much older than 18 some people think I look...they spiked my drinks even when I asked for no alcohol--"Oh, senorita, it tastes so much better with tequila!" "No thanks, I really want it without alcohol!" Thus I also learned to automatically pass my drinks to my dad for testing before I drank them. Wow, and what is it with guys and beer?? My dad takes supplement pills in the morning, and when we didn't have time for room service coffee or juice, what does he take them with?? Dos Equis XX! Um...ew. (The roomservice stocked our minifridge with sodas, water, and beer everytime they cleaned.) And I got my hand kissed for the first time...yeah, I ask for a towel so I can tan, and after I write down my name and room number on the receipt, he takes my hand and kisses it...um, thanks...can I get a towel now?...Miguel? Yeah. Caucun was very educational. Well aside from the rather obscure things I learned down there we went on a couple of tours and got to snorkel a lot and see some Mayan ruins (that was actually pretty cool). Oh, and on top of everything, thank you very much, you can see that I did not die from Jaime withdrawals! Yes, I missed her a lot, but she wasn't the only person I missed a lot, so there, hope everyone who reads this blog fully comprehends that! So anyway, I had a pretty good time, and overall I say it was worth the turbulent and slightly nauseating flights I endured to get down there. And another thing--good Lord, Spanish 1 doesn't go very far when you're actually in the Spanish element! Yup, I'm out of school now, but I'm keeping my vocab book for review! Ok, so pretty much I'm done now, but I just wanted to write about everything and tell everyone hi. James, thank you for updating the Fusion page!! Michael, I tried to bring you back a Stacie Ho lookalike, but to no avail. So I tried to find a postcard with some hot Latina chick on it, but either they were naked (or close enough), or they were some grotesquely fat woman in a string bikini...either way, I didn't think it'd be a good thing. Well, actually, I'm sure you wouldn't have minded a naked chick, but um...yeah, I'll have nothing to do with obtaining one for you. And I don't know if Ricky reads this blog, but if you do, I wanted to bring you back some sand like you wanted me to, but I don't think customs would have been pleased by that. And last but not least, Jaime, I missed you SOOO much, and I'll be calling you tomorrow. I love you all! ~Erika <>

Back from Costa Rica--June 19 - July 28 Wow. This past trip to Costa Rica was the oddest thing for me. Things happened between God and me that I didn't expect, as well as between other people and me. First of all, I was so grateful for the hotel we got to stay at, especially after the week-long village trip. (Those bugs bite hard! I still have marks on my skin where the bites were, and it was like, a month ago!) Thank God for hot showers!!! But anyway, between God and me...in my mind, I thought God would have me healing sick people left and right, seeing deliveration, things like that. No. To my rememberance, the only sick people I got to pray for one-on-one were in the youth group. But hey, God healed them on the spot! Well, so I was getting a little anxious and a bit worried when we were starting our third week there and I had not been the main witness to a huge miracle, such as the deaf lady getting healed at the "Plaza Del Pigeon." I talked to God about that, and I started feeling convicted because I had not taken the time to look at what had been done through me, regardless of what it was--I had prayed for lots of people for salvation, a couple people for some minor deliverances, and so what if the only sick people I prayed for were in our group? God did it through me anyway, and I felt bad because I had not been able to feel the honor that you should feel that God chose you to be His chosen vessel, no matter how "big," or how "small" our minds may think the miracle is. I started to realize how honored I felt when I brought in the net at the big Catholic church...I felt so nervous going up there, and then when I started talking, I said stuff that I hadn't even planned on saying...I could just feel God flowing through me. And then I'm guessing about 30 people came up to get saved, and I got to lead them all in the Sinner's Prayer...not everyone gets to help God save that many people at once. I was amazed, and when it was all over, I was on this huge adrenaline rush because of it--this joy that didn't really make any sense if I thought about how I used to think that just getting people saved was such a small task. I helped many more people get saved after that day, and I appreciated it every time. My level of boldness increased so much too--during the first part of the trip, I no more wanted to talk to one of those people than I wanted to jump off a cliff. By the time we did our last dramas at Cartago (the place with the ruins, drunks, and mating dogs aplenty), I was so ready to do it--I had no reserves or hesitations talking to anyone. It was such an incredible time of ministry for me. I plan on keeping that boldness here. Also, I found my calling in piano. I've had a sneaking suspicion about that for a while now, but when we got to CR, it was confirmed. I know that Michael, James, and Bobby have wanted me to step out and learn to improvise more on keys during worship. Well, that takes some skill--it's a little bit confusing to know how to play out of nowhere just...you know...out of nowhere. You have to know what notes blend with what chords, what combinations of chords you can put with base notes or chords...it's not just closing your eyes and playing whatever note your finger lands on. Or so I thought. My first experience with this was the worship service at Oasis. Jaime and I both agreed on her playing the bigger keyboard as a filler, mainly--to have a synth or strings sound the entire time to provide the background filller, pretty much. We also agreed that I should play the smaller one, which, we decided, would stay on a regular piano setting the entire time. We both knew that the smaller keyboard was the one to provide, if any, all of the improv. For some reason that didn't really occur to me until we were actually up there, and we were starting the actual service. You see, during much of the practice we had, I didn't personally have any problems with anything technical, because my keys and mic were some of the first things they set up for me. The main thing on my mind was that I had a black dirt smudge on my white shirt, and although a lot of people told me they could barely see it, I was convinced that the people in the back row would be able to see it quite clearly. You might say I was a bit distracted. Well, we got back from dinner, started service, and got into worship with the other worship team--they were really good. In fact, Jaime and I agreed that the guys playing keys made us feel like total losers. The times that the songs were just the kind you could jump around to, I admit that I was glaring with an unspoken envy at the guy on my keyboard. 'It's just not fair,' I thought. Then we got up there onstage. Everything was played pretty much as usual, on my end, until we got to Let it Rain. (And I'm sorry, but it totally sounds better in Spanish--it just kinda rolls off your tongue in that language.) I guess I had never thought of this before, but God put it into my head that of course, the notes you play in the chords are notes you can improvise with...that gives you up to four notes to mess with, and as far as keys are concerned, that's a nice selection. So I started to play around with it, and for some reason, it was really easy, and it totally clicked. By the time we were done in worship, I was very much enjoying this. I'm still not sure why I never thought of that before--it's kind of one of those "duh" moments. Well, I'm starting to do that more on the worship team here now, and it's so much fun! My piano teacher's still going to give me a book on chord improvisations, but anyway, I just thought I'd write about all that calling stuff. As for people, there was one person that I was completely changed by on this trip. Scott and I got a lot of things worked out on this trip, and I'd say as far as people in the group are concerned, my friendship with him is the most dynamic, and the most unexpected. Anyway, overall, Costa Rica was such a life-changing thing to me...God worked through me and taught me so many things that I'll never forget. I am so grateful for the opportunity I had to go, and if there's anyone who supported me who reads this blog, thank you so much--you'll never know how much it meant to me and to the people of Costa Rica. ~Erika <>

Letting Go--Sept. 21, 2003 Ok, I'm completely wowed by how long it's been since I've written! Sorry about that! Lately I've been feeling that God is really wanting me to improvise on keys more. To people who have been more or less "pushing" me to do that for the past several months (i.e., Michael, Bobby, James...cough), I really am grateful to you guys for that...I know you wouldn't have been asking me to do it if you didn't think I could. Anyway, aside from mainly Michael seriously wanting me to do this, I really have felt like although he has been adding (positive) pressure from the outside, God has been adding pressure from the inside out. It's been one of those things where I feel God wanting me to do it, but it's like standing on the edge of a cliff or something; it hasn't been time to jump; it hasn't been time for it to really happen yet. The kind of ironic thing is, improvisation on piano is something that seems so abundantly difficult to me, yet something that no one can teach, really. There are some things that you should know, like certain chords, inversions, and scales, and things like that. I'll be focusing on learning those things, and really just to sum it up, learning to let go to God. In some certain situations, taking risks is no big deal, but in other situations, I am so afraid to actually do it that I can never do it. It makes no sense at all, because whereas I am totally wanting to parasail, but playing a few notes that were not planned in front of people at youth who know me and have seen me screw up...I so did not want to do that. But now I'm willing to give it to God...it's the right time to start now. It's not like I expect to be doing solos at the next service we play at, but God will be stirring that up in me now, and it's really exciting to me because although I'm kinda nervous about it, I know God's going to meet me. He's not going to just let me do it on my own. So anyway, that's about it, but I thought I'd post that for anyone who's interested. ~Erika <>

Back to Normal--Nov. 8, 2003 As usual, it's been a long time since I've written, but I guess lately that's how it's been. When I first started writing, I wrote about every weekend, and now I only write about the ones that impact me or others I'm close to. Oh well. Saturday was pretty good, considering we didn't have our usual worship leader. It's nice having Michael there because things seem to run smoother; people seem to pay more attention. Not that nobody respected Bobby and Scott, but I don't know...Michael's the worship leader, and I guess that's just what we've all adapted to. That's not a complaint at all, just a thought. I think it's interesting how things seem a little lacking when we realize how much Michael really does lead us , not just the congregation. When he leads, he ministers to us , not just sings to the congregation. Anyway, so yes, worship practice was good, because, after all, Scott does know how to lead. The more I play, the more understanding I gain from it. Michael and I often have this little disagreement about playing with knowledge vs. playing without it. But the thing is, I seem to have some sort of faith complex when it comes to just getting up there and playing whatever I hear. Michael is constantly encouraging me to just step out and play it. I say, "Sure, I'll play it...when I know what those notes are." I'm afraid it's one of those circular arguments, but everytime we talk about that, I'm more encouraged to do it. Just step out and do it. So I pray about it and know that God is building it up in me, and every practice, I seem to be playing with a new piece of musical know-how in my head that I wasn't aware had been there before. Perhaps it's always been there, perhaps it hasn't. For instance, during worship, the actual worship with the congregation, I couldn't really concentrate on what I was playing as much because Bobby wanted me to sing. So one song, a slow one, it was just music, no vocals, and I listened to the guitars. I could somehow hear them more. I don't know if it makes sense as anyone reads this, but I could hear the individual notes more clearly. I couldn't quite place which notes they would be on my keyboard, but I knew the general vicinity, and if it was a black or white note. That's never happened before...the best you could've gotten out of me was which octave it was in, and on my keyboard, there aren't even three. So to all who belong to the "Erika needs to improvise" club, it really is happening. I think God made me not to be an impulsive person, but one who does things only when she's sure it's right. Either that or I'm just a total wimp. Whichever. The worship time as a whole was good. It was missing Michael's playing and singing, but Bobby, Nicole and Scott did a good job working together to make sure there was never anything truly missing. I was really surprised later, because I was praying with someone, and Bobby stepped up and sang for a while after the message. As usual, he did very well, even though he thinks he always sounds like crap. So anyway, I think that the night was really good for everybody...we flowed well and learned new stuff. I recall something someone said to me when I think about our team: God tells us to renew our minds, but He never tells us to stop. Maybe we're never supposed to stop growing, and although James isn't with us all the time, and Michael wasn't there that night, things are feeling back to normal. ~Erika <>

The War on Terrorism and Food for Thought With all this talk of the Iraqi war stuff and the capture of Saddam Hussein really makes me think. I just got done watching the first half of the presidential address on Fox. I asked my mom, "Now that we have Saddam, what are we going to do with him--can we kill him here, or what?" And she said, "Well, I think they're planning on sending him back to his country for his trial." However, we both agreed that we really hope they don't do that, even though they might not have a choice, because Saddam has so much power over there--so many people hate him, but his dedicated followers are still many and still violent. Iraq has a president, though--that's good news, although because of Saddam's previously mentioned followers, who's to say that president will last more than like, three days? I wish him luck. I also hope he has many bodyguards. I also think about what'll happen to Saddam Hussein. I'm kind of torn between what I think he deserves. Have you ever seen Law & Order or something and they let a guy off because he was mentally unstable when he committed the crime? That's kind of what I think about when I think about that evil man. Part of me wants to hate him because he's done so many horrible things to so many innocent people, and yet part of me wants to feel bad for him because of two reasons: One, have you ever seen a documentary of Saddam's life? The man had a horrible childhood and was raised in a Communist country in a Communist family. Being raised in a bad environment as a child definitely renders what a person will be like as an adult. I mean, if I were raised in Saddam's place, I could have his exact thought processes. A baby isn't born with vindictive, wicked thoughts engrossing it's brain. And culture counts for a lot too--for example, some girls and I were talking about how we have to shave and stuff, and I said, "Well, if you lived in France or some country where girls don't shave, you would never think about shaving--it would never occur to you to grab your husband's razor one day and shave off all your leg hair." In the same way, if you're raised in a Communist country, it can become part of your natural thought process to live with it without hesitation to its rules--unless you encounter someone who thinks differently. Like if you never, ever heard the word of God, the name Jesus would never have any validity to you, because although God's work is reflected in His nature, Jesus doing miracles and dying on the cross isn't--does this make any sense? So Saddam grew up in a culture that he thought natural, and obviously something happened to him to encourage him to do the things he does/did. Two, to God, me gossiping or slipping a cuss word sometimes isn't any worse than what Saddam's done to all those people combined. God loves him so much, and He died for Saddam's sins too. So if Saddam repented and accepted Christ, we'd totally see him in heaven when we die. God has just as much compassion for that man as he does for a tiny baby suffering (like Mike and Lynn's baby). And on a third hand (because I can't really say on the other hand, as most people only have two), he deserves to die some horrible, painful death, like what happened to some people who were martyred and stuff. It would only be justice embodied for him to give his life, or rather, have his life taken from him, in a terrifyingly violent and painful way. It would also be justice for every man or woman who helped him to die as well, as they have contributed to the suffering and depravity that is Iraq. Which is the right way? Regardless of mercy, I think the SOB should have to undergo some torturous form of "justice," like being eaten alive by those scarob-things from that movie, The Mummy; or have his skin ripped off of him, stop when he passes out, and resume when he regains consciousness (by the way, that wasn't something I just thought up, I read it in Jesusfreaks by dcTalk). And that's only pleasant compared to what he deserves. However, I am a Christian, and mercy is something I do consider quite frequently--which is the Biblically-correct, God-loving thought process for us Christians? Life or death, hatred or compassion? ~Erika <>

Youth on Jan. 17 and My Comfort Zone Theories Youth was really good for me this weekend. It was kinda weird because Pastor Rick's older d-group was gone, minus Nathan and Michael, so we had the regular backup singers, then Tom, Aaron, Weston, and Madison playing for the guys who were gone. Practice went pretty well, although we had to go over some stuff that the jv-band guys didn't know, or stuff like Obsession, which the varsity people didn't know. I was actually kind of surprised, because although I know that these guys are really good musicians, but they caught on really well. Of course things were different because Bobby and Scott weren't there and all that, but everything flowed actually better than I thought, though I'm a little sad to say I may have underestimated the younger guys. They really did well. As I get better at keys, I find myself wishing I had a really good keyboard. I mean, the one I play is fine, but the keys aren't weighted, and I don't care what people say-- the pedal does nothing !! It's really nice to feel more confident in my playing, though. It probably doesn't show that I feel better when I play, but I notice it. Every weekend I'm less afraid to try something I don't always do. Every weekend I'm less concerned when I make a mistake. This weekend, Michael asked me to keep playing some piano stuff during Obsession, which was unusually fine....typically I'm like, sitting there, trying not to panic, but it was fine, once I knew what he was talking about. The more I play, the more I really enjoy doing it. It makes me "step out of my comfort zone," as so many people are prone to saying. However, I think that that phrase is rather erroneously stated. You see, I've been playing keys for a couple of years now, and most of that time has been spent being encouraged by others to let God cultivate some kind of gifting, which I have done. Each weekend, God gives me a little bit of something that I never had before, and I can't really explain what that's like, but it's as though he's giving me the pieces of a puzzle, which, once I accumulate the right pieces, I can put together quite easily. So each weekend, if he gives me something, I don't just sit there and brood about it--I try to use it. That is supposed to be "stepping out of my comfort zone." But I'm not so sure about that. I mean, if you think about think about it, we never really leave our comfort zones. For a Christian, when we are saved, our best and most reliable comfort zone is automatically God, because of the new life and outlook on that life that he gives us. So we're saved, and after we've gained a bit of understanding of what this new life is, we start to share it with others in many ways. These are ministries. So if you're in a ministry, such as worship, there will be times when God asks you to do something you're not quite sure you have the resources to do--something you're not quite comfortable doing. When God tells me to do something on keys, sometimes it's easy and almost entirely effortless. And there are times when what he wants isn't what I would really like to do. So I might hesitate, but eventually, I will do it--I feel like I'm standing on a diving board and God's asking me to jump in. Eventually, though it may be rather grudgingly, I will lift one foot off the board, lean forward, close my eyes, and jump--well, ok, maybe just step off. But the anticipation of the water, the fear of not feeling something solid beneath me only lasts a few seconds, and then, quite a bit more suddenly than I anticipated, I'm in the water, in one piece and thinking I was an idiot for fearing such a small thing. That's what I sometimes feel like when I do something God wants. But when I think about it, I never stepped out of my comfort zone, I expanded it. I didn't step out of this nice, warm, safe comfort zone into this harsh, cold, unforgiving world of doing God's will. It's not like that. I took the step, yes, and it was temporarily scary, but when I hit the water, I realized that I was comfortable there. In the same way, if we take a step out into God's will, he won't leave us there alone, scared, and unarmed--he is with us every step of the way, and therefore, this new place is actually not so very unlike the one we just left. The discomfort we felt before was our blindness to the fact that our original comfort zone--God--never leaves us, nor does he shove us into doing these things without his help. He's with us every step of the way, and our huge, terrifying leap out of our wills is really just a small hop into another realm of God's will and his love for us--that original comfort zone. ~Erika <>

Wonders Never Cease...and Neither Will Stupidity "CHARLESTON, West Virginia (AP) -- An inmate who was stuck for four hours with his head and one shoulder through a cell window has been charged with felony escape. Robert Anthony Hill, 25, used a metal shelf to smash through the 6-inch-wide, 3-foot-long window at South Central Regional Jail on Monday, authorities said. Rescuers spent four hours cutting out the window frame and several blocks to free the prisoner. He was not seriously injured. Hill, who was charged Tuesday, faces five years in prison if convicted. He has been in jail since August on a parole violation after being charged with robbery and testing positive for drug use. He has previously served time for robbery, carrying a concealed weapon without a permit and joyriding. Authorities also were investigating whether other inmates tried to help Hill escape by slamming their lunch trays to mask the sound of breaking glass, said Steve Canterbury, executive director of the Regional Jail & Correctional Facility Authority." Smooth, dude, very smooth. Ok, this guy is trying to break out of jail and gets stuck in the window. Ya know, maybe it's just me, but I think if I were going to try to break out by climbing out the window I might--just might--see if perhaps said window was large enough to accomodate my HEAD! After reading this, I wonder two things: One, how ridiculous did this guy feel, realizing he's half in, half out of this window and he can't move?; two, how much did the guards laugh at him as they stood there, watching him perhaps trying to struggle in or out?
