Valentine's Day Alright, personally, I mostly despise Valentine's Day. The only time I used to like it was when I was little and I would come downstairs and my mom would have a little box of those wicked awesome candy hearts waiting for me. Yeah, I don't get those anymore--for some reason, those disappeared somewhat simultaneously with my abrupt atheism concerning Santa, the Easter Bunny, and the Toothfairy occurred. Why the candy hearts, though? I always knew my mother got them for me--how does that cause some kind of change?? Anyway, we were talking last night and she laughed and said she'd get me some this year--what a twisted world we live in when you have to lecture your own mother about how she's robbed you of childlike joy when she started denying you candy hearts every Valentine's Day. (I thought I'd interject here that if Freud were still alive and he read this, he'd most likely say that all my future/present emotional/psychological problems are due to my heartbreaking denial of candy hearts...hm.) Well actually, that's not why I mostly despise Valentine's Day, I just thought I'd throw that in there. The real reason is because typically I'm fine with the fact that I'm single, have been my entire life (unless you count my "going out" with a guy for six days at the end of sixth grade. Sheesh.), and the fact that I'm sixteen (almost seventeen) and never been kissed. Every other day of the year, it's usually ok with me--hey, I'm fine, I enjoy singlehood or whatever it's called. Until February 14th rolls around. Stores have the audacity to put out Valentine's crap right after they pack away all the Christmas stuff! So this is the one time of year where your nose is rubbed in the fact that you're single. How nice. And the fact that my mother is in a hideously good mood. Probably because she has a significant other. Whom she has a date with to her favorite sushi place of all time in Denver. (And I have no idea if the word "whom" was used in the correct context just now, because although I've sat through endless grammar classes, I've never grasped the concept of "who" and "whom" usage. If anyone has it figured out, please leave me a message in the comment section. Thank you.) And why do some relentlessly cruel people choose Valentine's Day to break up with their significant others? That is so mean! I've so many people who have told me someone broke up with them on Valentine's Day--man, can we get a little more sadistic? At least I can say no one's ever dumped me on Valentine's Day...so I guess I could have it worse. Oh, and by the way--guys, if you are buying someone something for Valentine's Day, please remember to take the price tag off! I have to tell this story because I think of it every Valentine's Day and it makes me laugh: in eighth grade, my friend Denise was going out with this guy named Joey. Everything was fine, and although I personally thought he was a sociopath, I, as well as the group of people Denise and I hung out with, supported them going out. Ha. So on Valentine's Day, Joey came up to her and gave her this gift bag thing, and when he walked away, she opened it. A chocolate rose and a silver necklace with this little crystal-studded heart-shaped charm on it. Sweet. So her first words are, "I wonder if it's real!" All of us knew it wasn't, but we left Denise to her delusions of grandeur and her eutopic Cloud Nine for the rest of the day until I, the Genius, had to open my mouth and say, "Can I see the boxthe necklace came in?" I take the box, flip it over, and on the bottom is the unmistakable price tag which said, "$5.00." I tried to take the tag off before she saw it, but too late. Oh well, she still thought it was cute regardless (and I mean, hey, it's eighth grade, do you think he was gonna buy her this platinum and diamond-crested article of jewelry??). So anyway, two days later, she comes to me, sobbing, and chokes out, "Joey...(sniffle)...he...(wracking sob)... dumped me!! " Of course, we all comforted her, yada yada, and then the next day she transitioned from her brokenhearted stage to her raging, furious, vindictive stage. (They only went out for like a week and a half, but maybe she thought he was The One...whatever.) So she took the chocolate rose (which she had simply refused to eat, plucked the chocolate part off, and shoved the barren stem into his locker, which he never locked. (It was Calhan Middle School--stealing?? Who steals in Calhan?) Along with the stem, she hung his necklace and a note which I never really saw, but knew the words, "five-dollar piece of crap" were vehemently enscribed upon it. Ah...young love. Anyway, I just thought I'd put all that out there because I find it highly amusing. And hey, Jaime and I are getting each other chocolates, and my mom's getting me my long-sought-after candy hearts. Although I do think it's a little sad when you have your mother and best friend as your only consolation, but whatever, I'll take what I can get--single life is still good. Happy Valentine's Day!! ~Erika <>

Worship Styles--Including Guys Jumping Off Chairs Worship: to regard with ardent or adoring esteem or devotion. I guess blogs are useful because it gives you an outlet in which to talk about things you wouldn't just get up and shout from the mountaintops. I've been thinking a lot about worship, and how different people portray it. For instance, a certain guy on the worship team is really into getting onstage and telling people that if they're not jumping around, then why are they there?, you need to give God your all, etc. Pretty much this blog entry is a gripe. Bear with me--I have a lot of scattered thoughts I'm trying to form into one point here. Although I wholeheartedly agree that when you're worshiping you should give your all for God, I disagree about the worship statements written above. When I wasn't on the worship team, I would be in the congregation towards the front. That's where I always was. Then I started thinking/praying about it, and I realized that the only reason why I was up front was because I felt like I should be. It wasn't because I wanted to worship God up front, it was because I thought people would think that maybe I was "ashamed" if I worshiped in the back. From that point on, I did worship in the back of the sanctuary with no guilt. In fact, it made my time with God more intimate because there was no one around me, and I could just focus on Him, not what other people were seeing me do. I think that everyone has their different way of worshiping their creator, and I don't think there is necessarily a right or wrong way, as long as you're doing what you feel God is wanting you to do. I for one am not big on jumping during worship. When I do devos at home, I jump sometimes, but for the most part, while I jump and dance or whatever in God's presence occasionally, it's not always my "style." However, just because I'm not hopping around does not mean that my time with God is not sincere, and does not prove that He's not speaking to me at that time, nor does it mean that I am ashamed of Him. I get really sick of comments made by people, referring that your physical activity during praise is a monument to how much God is talking to you, moving you. Does it really matter whether you flail madly during praise or stand still, hands in your pockets, staring straight ahead? I don't think so. I don't have anything against people whose styles lean towards jumping around. However, someone standing still could be having a more intimate experience with God at that time than the person screaming or jumping off chairs. (And yes, I do remember someone who jumped off of chairs during worship and nearly landed on me. I'm not writing this out of a personal vendetta though, just in case you were thinking, 'Ah-HA! Now I see why she feels so strongly about this!'.) Does it really matter if, during a slow song, you are on your knees, your face, standing, sitting, hands lifted, arms down, eyes open or closed? I doubt it. I think the only thing that matters is your focus on the one who calls you His own. If you have to jump, sit, cry, whatever to achieve that zone of intimacy with God, you go ahead. But I really can't stand when people tell the entire congregation that you need to jump to show your worship to God. It's not a matter of what you look like when you're worshiping, because your outward presentation is a performance of emotion entirely. Think about it: do you ever start praising God and you just can't sit still, so you get up and dance around or something? It's because you can't contain how God's presence is making you feel. Sometimes His presence hits you so hard you start crying. But not everyone reacts the same way to God's power, you see. Our outward expression is what we do because we love God and it's what we feel like doing for Him. If you're not raising your hands because it's not what you feel like doing for God, then don't! We shouldn't have to put on a show to let people know where we are with God, because the truth is, it's none of their business. This is probably why the Bible talks about praying and stuff behind closed doors with the windows shut--because that way you're praying and worshiping just one-on-one with God, and not with anyone else. Your time with God is your time with God, whether you do it in your bedroom, the shower, in a sanctuary, in the car, whatever. My point is, I wish people would stop trying to pressure the congregation into showing the worship leader or whoever what he/she wants to see the congregation doing. As a worshiper on a worship team, yeah, it's great to look up and see people raising their hands, jumping around, getting excited for God, but that's not what it's about. It would mean so much more to hear that somebody came up to someone on the team and said, "Hey, thanks for doing worship, I really spent some great time with God tonight." I feel that way because I'm on the worship team because I love ministering worship to people. And worship is so much more than just an outward appearance, it's a way to for us to be with God through music. I guess what I'm really trying to say is, if you want to kneel, kneel to God; if you want to sing, sing to God; and if you want to dance in worship, dance for God, not for who may be watching. ~Erika <>

Quandaries Ok, I was watching my Bible class today (since I'm homeschooled under Abeka, I'm supposed to take a Bible class--the semester, it's "New Testament: Jesus and His Followers"), and the lesson was about the crucifixion of Jesus, and the different events that took place before it. Typically, when I think of Jesus, I think about him in a more "today" point of perspective, not so much of him during the Bible days. However, I've been thinking about him as more of the Biblical figure lately, due in majority to the fact that Easter is coming up, and so is The Passion of Christ or whatever it's called. This time of year always makes me think of what Jesus did for us. So in thinking of Jesus, and how he was when he walked this earth, I wondered what kind of person I would have been if I had lived where he did miracles and stuff when he did them. Would I have been one of the women he healed or saved, or one of the Pharisees who hated him? A Roman soldier who helped whip/beat/crucify him and cast lots for his robe? If you think about it and are honest with yourself, would you be the kind of person who just worshiped at his feet? Because really, in those days, he was kind of a freak. People just didn't go around raising people from the dead and calling the Pharisees "you pit of vipers" on an everyday basis then, you know? How do you react when you see a radical on the street or some punk with like twenty piercings (and those are only the ones visible to you at the time) and covered in tattoos? Or some gross, drunk, homeless man on the street who'd just as soon murder you for one good meal as look at you? If I had lived where Jesus had, and had been living a life full of sin, I don't know that I would have loved him unless he personally changed my life. I think I would have thought he was a total freak, scoffed at him with my friends as he walked by, and, more to the point, judged him before I really knew him. Then maybe--just maybe--when I saw him on the cross, I would have been moved. Maybe not. Maybe I would have been one of the Roman soldiers who, even though they were so close to his cross, were too busy seeing if they could win his clothing by luck rather than look at the One who the clothes belonged to. So close, and yet too preoccupied with trivial matters to see what he was doing for them--the anguish he suffered, the loneliness he must've felt, knowing his father had forsaken him, the humiliation of being on that cross, but the joy of knowing what freedom we all would have the opportunity to experience as soon as it was all over with. Thinking of this reminds me of one of my all-time favorite songwriters and singers, Nichole Nordeman. There's a song she wrote called "Wide Eyed," and since it's such a long song, I'll just write part of it: "Not so long ago, a man from Galilee Fed thousands with his bread and his theology And the truth he spoke quickly became the joke Of educated, self-inflated Pharisees like me And they were wide-eyed in disbelief and disillusion They were tongue-tied, drawn by their conclusions Would I have turned and walked away And laughed at what he had to say And casually dismissed him as a fraud Unaware that I was staring at the image of my God" Which part would you play? ~Erika <>

More on Worship To James: I really learned so much from your post on Fusion Worship--thank you for the enlightenment. To Michael: I had to read your post a few times through to fully grasp what you were saying, but I get it now. Our opinions differ a bit, but probably because I've never led worship, and you're right--I don't know what it's like, nor do I profess to. I think in my Worship Styles post I got a little off-track. Just to clarify, when I was talking about how it bothers me when worship leaders say, "If you're not jumping, then what are you here for?", I don't think that that's necessarily wrong, depending on the circumstances. Due to both James's and Michael's blogs, I understand better why worship leaders do that. When I wrote that post, I was writing strictly from the point of view of someone who has never led worship and probably never will--to my knowledge, that's not my calling. As far as worship leaders go, I think what I was trying to say was this: sometimes they come off as a little negative/condemning. Like James said, there's a difference between pressure and encouragement. I suppose to me, when I know I am very much in God's presence, hearing someone say stuff that sounds a bit harsh seems well--a bit harsh, because I was participating. I do see more how it must be really frustrating when the congregation is not "getting into it," and that yes, sometimes some less than gentle words should be spoken. When I wrote that post, I wasn't writing to say, "If you say that stuff right now, you're wrong," or "If you said that stuff three months ago, you're wrong." My post was not focused on one time period. Just period. In my opinion, as well as others' I've spoken to, it seems that when worship leaders lead, they lead us all into the very throne room of God by way of music. (That is, of course, if we're all willing to follow him/her there.) However (and correct me if I'm wrong), shouldn't it be up to God, who knows all hearts, what we do once we arrive there? If a worship leader says, "Ok, everyone, start jumping now!" how could they be sure that jumping is everyone's sacrifice to God? For me, sometimes it definitely is, but sometimes, it's equally as sacrificial for me to stand still and listen, even though everyone around me is jumping and stuff. Please don't think I'm saying that worship leaders should never encourage their congregants to do whatever God's will is--hey, it's not like I always know what that is, so you know...--I was just saying that sometimes leaders can come off as a little edgier than maybe they might mean to. A few weeks ago, Pastor Rick talked about how sometimes people get offended when he starts talking about something that means a lot to him. The reason why is because he gets carried away by his passion for that subject. That's exactly what I'm talking about. As a congregant and someone who doesn't lead worship, my point is, to all worship leaders who read this, by all means, encourage, but just be careful that your passion and your heart for worship doesn't come out as more forceful than is necessary. (Wow, did I use enough commas in that sentence??) I hope I didn't offend anyone (by my passion for this subject, hahaha!), and as I have soaked up what I've read from others, I hope other worship leaders understand this more. Because all the other musicians/singers and I are not worship leaders, we try to do our best to follow you. You are our leader, and we will go anywhere you lead us. Thankfully, no matter what anyone says in the microphone or whether we jump or be still, by your willingness to let God flow through you, in our following you, we will never fail to end up directly before the feet of our Savior. To the worship leaders--thank you for your obedience to God, for without it, our journey from our flustered mental states into the very essence of God would be so very blind. ~Erika <>

Immaturity I strongly disagree with people who think that maturity should come with age. Personally, there have been times where circumstances in life have forced me to grow up rather more quickly than the natural progression of time would have. Other times, or in other situations I might say, I am such a little kid still. Allow me to deconstruct: 1. While working in the Buckle, we have to offer registration, primo cards, and the Buckle charge card. This very middle-aged man was buying some shoes for his wife, and when he snapped at me, declining each offer I told him about, I smiled at him, politely said, "Ok, that's fine," and read him his total. In my mind, though, I had a sudden urge to stomp off and sulk. 2. When Jaime and I came home (well, my full-time home, Jaime's part-time home) on Saturday night, I got out of the car to open the garage door and found that our psychopathic barn cat, Romo, had left the bottom half of a mouse to greet me. Um, ew. (I swear, that cat is the reincarnation of Jeffrey Dahmer. When he hunts [i.e. brutally murders] his prey [i.e. victims], he leaves them for us, but in such a calculating way that it scares me. Sometimes he'll kill a mouse and leave it face-down, and when you flip it over out of morbid curiosity, you'll see that all the insides are gone and the mouse is competely deflated. Feline freak.) Anyway, so I see this mouse, and I notice Romo haunting nearby, as if he's waiting to see my reaction. My mouth drops open and I look at Jaime in the car, then to Romo (I'm telling you, he was psychotically smiling), then back at the mouse. My first instinct was to kick the cat, then to bury the mouse. Yes, I did say 'bury the mouse.' 3. My dad was on TDY for work this week, and my mom and I watched Cold Creek Manor together, in which a guy is stalking this couple with a mallet used for when his dad used to kill sheep with it. Or something like that. So I'm a total wimp anyway, and even though the movie really wasn't that scary, just kind of creepy, I was really not wanting to go outside to bring the dogs in. I mean, really really not wanting to go. Like as if some mad murderer was lurking right outside the front door, waiting to bash my brains in with a mallet-sheep-killing-thing. Last I checked, the only mad murderer outside my front door is my Jeffery-Dahmer-so-called-cat. Go figure. Not only do I have to steel my nerves before opening the door, I actually run--not walk--back inside and slam/lock the door. 4. I often have the habit of laughing at inappropriate times. When I was little, my mom would get mad at me and threaten me--you know, getting spanked, beheaded, disemboweled--the usual. So when she would start on that, there was just something in me (probably Satan) that made me start cracking up. It didn't matter what she said, I could not stop laughing. Even now, when she gets mad at me, I have to fight the urge to burst out laughing. Or sometimes in a movie when someone dies some horrible, awful death by flailing down a flight of stairs or something I can't help laughing. Or when Jaime spends the night or something and we're like, "Ok, we're going to sleep now," and say goodnight, the lights are out and it's totally silent--and I start cracking up. 5. I hate spiders. I don't know why. The word 'phobia' is described as something like 'an irrational fear of something that compels one to avoid it, even with the knowledge that the thing is not dangerous.' I suppose you could say I am mildly phobic of spiders if you must use that word. I have never been traumatized by a spider, and if it's a tiny one, I can usually kill it myself. But there's just something about the way they move that totally freaks me out--therefore, if I see a big one in my room, my immediate response is to jump, shriek, and start dancing uncertainly on the spot where I stand. Then I start screeching, "DAAAAD!!! EWW, A SPIDER!!! DAAAAAD, KILL IT!!" It doesn't matter how much older I get, I will always be scared/grossed out by spiders. This is how I've been ever since I was little, although now I don't actually start screaming and crying. 6. Christmas Eve is still the most exciting thing for me, ever. I don't care what happens, Christmas Eve is always exciting. Ever since I can remember, I've spent every Christmas Eve tossing and turning in bed, unable to sleep because the curiosity of what could be under the tree is just constantly jabbing at the edge of my mind. I tell no lie--even now, almost seventeen years old, completely in disbelief of Santa, and knowing fully well that we have no chimney for him to squeeze down even if I did believe in him, I still hallucinate reindeer hooves on our roof. I still also have to push back the instinct to ask if we could make cookies to leave for him. Not that it would matter, since if we did, the selfish teenager in me would eat all the dough before it even hit the cookie sheet. 7. Ever since I had teeth, I put off flossing until like the day before I went to the dentist (as if the dentist could never in a million years tell that my teeth had just been flossed the night before). Now, since I'm older and ever so much smarter and more intelligent, I have upped my time before the dentist to a whole--count them, now-- seven days before the dentist. I have a week before my next appointment, and guess who's flossing tonight before going to bed? Guess who hasn't flossed consecutively for the last four months? So yeah, that's me, the girl a lot of people think is really smart. Ha. If you are one of these people, please re-read the section on my fear of mad murderers outside my front door. Man or cat. Doesn't matter. Yes, so anyway, I had fun writing this anyway, so I don't care if it makes me sound really stupid. I'm remembering happy childhood memories as I type and really trying to remember this book I read once as a little kid--something about a Mrs. Swamp or something. When I remember the name, I'm going to find it and read it again. I suggest everyone find a childhood book and re-read it, even if the sentences only consist of three words. I think the only way someone truly gets old is if they lose the "immaturity" that sometimes makes life worth living. ~Erika <> PS- Michael, I just thought I'd tell you that the words "childish and immature" were laughingly floating through my head during the entire process of writing this blog entry. To all of you who know me pretty well (that's you, Jaime, Michael, and Vicky), I ask you to please refrain from filling my comment block with certain conversations or actions I have engaged in that bear resemblance of something a little different from childhood innocence. I believe it would severely diminish the sentimental revelry I am currently floating around in at this point in time. ;o) PPS- Does anyone besides me remember when if you disagreed with someone, you said, "Nuh-uh!", and they'd reply with, "Yah-huh!" Or "I know you are, but what am I?" Or "I am rubber, you are glue...etc." Please tell me all of us 1987-ers remember that!

Ok, I don't know if anyone else will find this funny, but I read this guy's blog, and this particular post totally cracked me up: Got Advertising Rants? by Kaya I think we can all agree that it is no longer an effective marketing strategy to mimic the successful Got Milk? ads. Please -- can we agree to stop copying this tagline? The once proud and mighty Got Milk? slogan has lost its steam. It served its purpose, now its time to let it take its natural course. Much like the wave at sporting events or Dan Aykroyd, its time to put it to sleep and out of misery. Aside from the grammatical error in the Got Milk? slogan, it is a brilliant ad campaign (and, lets face it, Do You Have Milk? sounds stupid and doesnt fit easily on a black t-shirt). Each advertisement was expertly executed and I imagine its one of the most recognized marketing runs of all time. But I have a questiondid anyone really buy more milk due to this multi-million dollar ad buy? Isnt milk one of those things you either use or dont use? If they advertised heavily for the use of salt or butter (not a particular brand, but the substance unto itself) would you use more of it? Maybe its because I drink soy milk (and feel that Got Phlegm? is a more appropriate tagline despite what the focus group say) that this drink milkany milk at all strategy doesnt make sense to me. Everyone knows milk is supposed to be good for you (notwithstanding several studies raising points to the contrary), so how does this ad make you desire more milk in your diet? Does anyone say, This ad really spoke to me. I think Ill start pouring milk on my cereal in the mornings instead of beer or grenadine. Or Dunking these freshly baked chocolate chip cookies into mugs filled with sand isnt hitting the spothey, do we got milk? Perhaps the worst result from these successful dairy spots was the copycat ads. Usually in the form of a local business or small company, the Got _____? text appeared to be everywhere. Got Life Insurance?, Got Bagels?, Got Estate Planning? I even saw printed on the window of a car Got Good Grades? as a promotion for a tutoring service. No, I dont got good grades -- my tutor cant write a sentence correctly. I cant count how many times I saw this clever copywriting piggyback being done, however, I knew it was truly over when I saw a sign that read Got Smoked Fish? Yep. The official end. Like when Bob Saget began to wear a goatee, thus signaling it was no longer cool (and perhaps one of the signs of the apocalypse), the Got Smoked Fish? slogan is the checkered flag, the rolling credits and the final bow to this once successful tagline. Rest in peace little fella. May your message of strong bones and sturdy teeth help you where you go next. Say hello to the surly Wheres the Beef? lady and the poor Ive Fallen and I Cant Get Up. woman. I hope you got life insurance before it was too late. Godspeed.

Small Towns Alright, you know, I live kind of between Calhan and Falcon, but not exactly in either town. I've noticed that in spite of the fact that subdivisions are piling up out here and they're building more stores, shopping centers, etc., the small town mentality is still running strong for some of these people. Examples: (A) I walk into Safeway after work one day to get a Starbucks, wearing a skirt. It's not like it was dressy or anything, just a black skirt and a t-shirt with flip-flops. Celebrities and Christianity I've been thinking about something that I heard on some show on E!, and the commentator of the show said something like, "People don't really care about a celebrity's career, what they all really want to know about is the star's personal life." For some reason, that popped into my head a couple of days ago, and I think that that statement radiates a lot where our roles as Christians in this world are concerned. Has anyone noticed that no one really cares about Michael Jackson's career anymore? All the newspapers talk about is his involvement with children, trials, and scandals--not his latest cd or newest dance moves. Paris Hilton is mostly famous not because she's a beautiful heiress, but because of her appearances at wild parties and in porn videos. When Janet Jackson caused such a scandal at the Superbowl, it was not because what happened involved her , but because of what her motives might have been. Bill Clinton--quick, think!--when you read his name, did you just think of his stigmatic involvement with Monica Lewinsky? That particular event had nothing to do with his ability to lead our country, but what kind of a person he was. People thought, "What kind of a president do we have? How can a man that immoral really be in any kind of shape to direct this nation??", when in reality, how many people have been involved in acts of adultery? The statistic would be innumerable. The media focuses on a celebrity's personal life, emotions, and activities because in such an Americanized and godless culture, the public still yearns for an ability to relate to that celebrity. If you hear a great song on the radio, you listen for the artist's name, look for the cd, buy it, love the music, and then what? You listen to his music with great interest, look at the face of the artist on the cd's sleeve, look for his name, read the lyrics he wrote. If you are intrigued by what you hear, see, and read, you might just go online and look him up. Why? Because you want to know more about him as a person. America is filled with people searching for truth or reality (or something like it) by following the lives of those who are famous. They want to reach out and be reached out to. They search for beautiful, talented people who are in some ways like themselves so they feel a degree of closeness to an "idol," a "deity." As much as the common man denies the existence of something higher than himself, he sure does treat other common men as such. Oh, wait, I'm sorry, those other common men are "famous," they're "celebrities,"...my mistake, I apologize. Other common men --perhaps the thought of loving a God, an entity high in the sky, is too much to handle and quite unreal or irrational, but the thought of loving and obsessing over another of the same species is much easier to swallow. As humans, we crave company. We are social creatures, of course with the exception of hermits and such. Most people, even if they don't love being in a huge crowd, enjoy the company of a few close friends. We all like to have friends, people we can relate to. My point in processing this is that as Christians, what more do we need to show people how much God loves them? Humans are reaching out to other humans to find a source of identity because they feel that they can't reach out to God, or that God doesn't want to or won't reach out to them. Even if you don't speak to someone directly about God every day, there are always ways to show his love to them. I'm not writing this to tell you all to get up and go scream to people on the sidewalk that "Jesus loves you!!", but to enlighten you to the fact that we all need to look at the normal, everyday people around us and see how much those who don't have God need him, and need to understand how all God wants is to have a loving, intimate, yet casual relationship with each and every one of us. So many people, including many Christians, are ignorant to the fact that God took away that veil of separation and irreconciliation when he sent his son to die for us all. Because of that, there's no reason to think that he's far from us--and that is exactly what this culture needs to know: God doesn't even want his people to treat him as so "untouchable" as a celebrity is, but only wants them to love him and crave knowledge of and friendship with him. ~Erika <>

Back from Cancun Alright everybody, we're back from Cancun, and A) no, we didn't wind up on any Girls Gone Wild Videos, B) no, we did NOT tan topless, and C) yes, we did see VERY hairy men by the pool. Ugh. For those of you wondering, our trip was very good and very relaxing. For the most part, our agenda went as follows: My mom woke us up at about 10 a.m. We got up, threw on some clothes and makeup, and went to breakfast. We went back up the the room, changed into bathing suits, and went to the pool. I would tan and Jaime would lie in the shade, applying sunscreen every twenty minutes. We would get hot and get in the pool. Work Pilates into our schedule. Some days we had spa appointments, like massages, facials, and pedicures. Go up to the room and take a nap. Get up and shower. Go down to dinner and get a drink from Manuel, the coolest bartender ever. (He speaks Mexican AND Mayan--how awesome is that??) Go to bed. James thinks I'm a loser for not blogging while I was down there, but honestly, looking at that action-packed schedule, how on earth could I possibly fit in the time?? Plus, I'm not really sure they had internet access. Like I think the website said they did, but it was never mentioned to us, and I never saw any place to access. Oh, and we went parasailing! How cool is that? We went up tandem, which means we went up together, which is good, because I'm not sure I could've done it by myself. I didn't really let myself think about it because I knew I'd get all scared if I did, so I kind of blocked it out until we got on the Waverunner, it took us out to the boat, and we got harnessed onto the parachute. Then I got scared. They put me in front and Jaime behind me, so when we got up there, the ocean was right there . It was so much fun though, because it was so quiet and serene--it seemed really surreal to me while I was up there because the ocean was so beautiful it almost looked fake. I had my eyes closed for like the first five seconds, and Jaime was all psyched and saying, "Open your eyes, open your eyes!!" so I did and was amazed. I guess I thought maybe the air/wind would make it really rough up there, but it was like floating. I also thought we'd have to scream at each other to be heard, but there was total silence. As soon as I relaxed, it was just unbelievable, and I'm so glad we did that. I think we were probably about as high up as you are when you get to the top of the Mind Eraser at Elitches before the drop, and we were up there for about nine minutes (too short if you ask me). I would do it again in half a heartbeat if I could. The food there was really good, though I think we all thought the buffets at dinner were the best. The first night we got there, we had a buffet, and they had these awesome desserts. The rest of the dinners were from a menu, and the last night we had a Mayan/Mexican buffet, which was pretty interesting and really good. They had all these food displays every night, and I think the coolest one was an alligator made of bread, which sounds dumb but actually was really cool (and James, I took a picture of it so you can see it). The Mayan buffet had this donkey's head made out of various melon, and it looked really interesting to me, but Jaime didn't have her camera, so I didn't get a picture of it. (Though she didn't really mind because it kind of scared her.) The last day, we went snorkeling in Cozumel, which was definitely fun, although we did have to take a ferry across the way, and that was bad cuz the currents were really strong and I felt like I was gonna hurl. When we got to the Cozumel pier, we walked to a glass-bottomed boat tour and got to go to three different snorkeling sites. The first was really good with a lot of fish, but the second was even better because we got to see/hold sand dollars and this enormous starfish. The guide would dive down and bring them up to us. The third site Jaime will have to write about because by that point, since I don't think I had fully recovered from the ferry ride, I was feeling sick again and stayed in the boat. Apparently there were some HUGE fish, like four-feet-long fish...the guide chased one under the boat so I could see it, which was cool. We went shopping after snorkeling and Jaime and I got these really pretty silver rings and henna tattoos, which I think are really fun. (Although since my tattoo is like this sun thing, and I haven't totally gotten used to it, I got in the bathtub today and for a fraction of a second had this panic cuz I forgot it was there and thought it was a spider or something.) I'm seriously hating Colorado's weather, because it's really inhumane to have to come home from 80-degree-plus weather and then the next day be in nasty rainy/snowy crap like today had. And now it's all sunny. What is with this stupid weather?? Anyway, just thought I'd let you all know how Cancun was--we had a great time, and as sarcastic as my last blog sounded, you guys were actually missed. Occasionally. Between drinks and naps. ~Erika <>

Update Please forgive the silence. I don't have an imaginatively creative and clever excuse. My only lame excuse is, I've just had a total writer's block. I've had nothing much of note to blog about, but since a few people have told me I need to blog, I suppose I should at least just put something out here. Life has been relatively busy, which is how I like it. It's easier for me to get some kind of routine going in my lifestyle when I have a lot to do, and I like routines in my life. One of the biggest things I've seen people blog about and heard people talk about is the big stuff going on with the church division and concerning the youth ministry. Really, everyone who's blogged about it has covered most of the high points that have been running through my mind. To be honest, I am grateful for this change of pace. I love the idea of change, but sometimes it's not in "my timing," therefore making it hard to adapt to. However, this was not the case. The only thing I was really upset about was the fact that a lot of people were hurt, and the youth ministry was noticeably diminished, especially considering how many people have graduated as well. I am the kind of person who very quickly adapts to changes though, and I was thrilled when I heard that Roger and Rachel are the new youth pastors. I know they'll do an amazing job, and if I'm telling the truth, I think Pastor Rick had taken us as a ministry as far as he could. It was time for fresh wood to be thrown on the fire, and Roger and Rachel have it in mass. I am really grateful for what Rick did in this ministry, after all, God used him to basically build it. But that season is over, and I anticipate the future with excitement. I was thinking to myself today that yeah, things are bound to be a little strained for a little while, but God didn't leave with Rick. We're gonna be fine, and in moving on, people will heal as well as the ministry. I say, let's put the past behind us and renew ourselves spiritually for what great things God has for us now. Ok, so for all these other people "covering all the high points," I guess I had some things to say anyway. Well, all that aside, personally speaking, life is pretty good. I've gotten to better know some people who I've been acquainted with for years, and I always think that's interesting. Making new friends is always cool to me. I've also, as Jaime wrote, been hanging out with her and Michael more, which is fun since we haven't really been able to do that for quite a while. I've noticed a lot of things happening in various relationships, with many different people, that I find interesting because you can kind of see friendships and things forming that are more long-term, now that so many of us only have a year of high school left. I can see in myself that my friends have become extremely important to me in the past half a year or so, and it's strange now to realize that this coming year is the last year I'll have in high school and as a legal minor. In about 15 months, I'll be a freshmen in high school. Even though I know it's not totally true, I can't help but feel that this last year is going to form who I'll be as an adult. This last year means a lot to me, maybe because I know a lot of people will probably wind up leaving for college and things, and this last year might be the last year I have with them. Yeah, all that sounds kind of sad, but that really just motivates me. I mean, this last year counts for a lot for some reason, and I can tell that I'm really going to want to make it count, if that makes any sense. Really I guess what I'm trying to say in this blog right now is that I'm really excited for the future, and what change has brought into it. Even though change is somewhat unnerving at times, I feel that if we let that go to God and relax, he'll really take things to the next level, and we should be ready for what he's going to do in our ministry. ~Erika <>
